instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.CHGR_PHASE: What is CHGR_PHASE? CHGR_PHASE is charger voltage chopped up into individual slices prior to smoothing where it becomes PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi Guys. 

Another Air :) 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> - 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>P3V42G3H_SW</SIGNAL> - 8.2v

L7560 - 4.8v
L7520 - 5.2v

<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_DRVH</SIGNAL> - 10v 
<SIGNAL>P5V_S4RS3_DRVH</SIGNAL> - 5.4

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
5V at L7520 means the board is turned on.
Check for voltage at other big coils; apart of L7520/60.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
L7630 - 1.05v
L7430 - 1.2v
L7560 - 3.3v
L7520 - 5v
PP3v42 is 3.4v

The board doesn't have any liquid damage or corrosion but someone played around with the bios chip it was heated up but not taken out. The SMC looks good. I don't have a fan spin even though I have the needs voltages to power on. Also i checked for shorted lines i couldn't find anything wrong.  Maybe reprogramming the bios would help :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I noticed on L7560 on pin 1 i have 5v and on pin 2 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Stop to check buck converter coils on incorrect pin!
ALWAYS measure DC voltage on the output (DC side), where the filter cap is placed.

No voltage at all at L7310/20?.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> comes on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  is 0.1
No voltage on :7310/20
The SMC I reflowed no change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
You must get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> first.
Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and check it again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: With removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> when measured on pic 4 ( <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> ) goes up to 3v and goes down again. Now <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL> is going up and down also

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>1V5_S0</SIGNAL> pulsing the same as other volatges?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>1V5_S0</SIGNAL> steady at 1.5v with <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> on the board and without <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> shows sometimes very quickly 1.5v and drops to 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Let <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> out of board.
Try starting in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: With  <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> of the board it triggers the power button pads for power but nothing happens just goes back to 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"it triggers the power button pads for power"
I said try SMC bypass, not just trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Even with SMC Bypass no change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Yes same  <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>  when I try to measure goes up and down right away

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
If someone else worked on it, you can expect missing components, or broken trace.
Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Morning :)

I was checking the S0 Enables and found that (<SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>) was missing and  <RESISTOR>R8187</RESISTOR> was moving and saw that under the resistor the contact was broken. I just rewired it and it powered on. 

Thanks you for your help 2informaticos I really appreciate it ✌🖖
